_prev_prog_3.Description: SuperValu's implementation of the PSM Program includes employee education in the hazards of ammonia and measures that can be used to reduce employee and community exposure to accidental releases. The plan includes a regular preventative maintenance program (mechanical integrity) for the ammonia system components, and a program for both pre-startup safety reviews and management of change(MOC)to the ammonia refrigeration system. The program also includes operating procedures for the safe operation of the refrigeration system, specific requirements safe work practices (such as safe approaches to welding and similar hot work), and safety requirements for contractors who may be hired to work on the refrigeration system. Supervalu has a procedure in place for investigating incidents to ensure root causes are identified and corrective actions are taken to minimize potential for recurrence of incidents. The program also has a component for conducting compliance audits to ensure the PSM program is being implemented at the Indianola facility. Lastly the PSM Program incorporates the facilities emergency response plan and places special emphasis on handling accidental releases of ammonia and coordination of emergency response activities with the local fire department and other response agencies.

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
SuperValu Foods Distribution Center

Indianola, Mississippi 

Risk Management Program 
Executive Summary


1.0 Purpose 
To provide a Risk Management (RMP) program executive summary of the anhydrous ammonia 
refrigeration system. 

2.0 Background 
Chemical Risk Management started in various management practices developed in different 
process industries. Because of industrial accidents involving releases of hazardous chemicals 
effective process safety management techniques were mandated by the EPA and OSHA to be 
developed by affected facilities. 

3.0 PSM Structure 
Process Safety Management is the application of management principles and systems to the 
identification, understanding, and control of process hazards to protect employees, facility assets, 
and the environment. As represented in the figure below, multiple forces impact the systematic 
development of PSM and its relationship within the organization. 

Regulations Community 

Employees 
Practices and Procedures 
Management 
Systems 
Policies 
Environment Economics 
Service Standards 
PSM Program Structure 



4.0 Requirements 
This program has been designed to address the requirements of the Occupational Safety and 
Health Administration 29CFR1910.119, Process Safety Management of Highly Hazardous 
Chemicals and 40 part 68 Chemical Accident Prevention Provisions (RMP). In the design and 
implementation of RMP / PSM elements, existing company safety guidelines, employee 
participation and involvement practices, ammonia system operating procedures, maintenance 
guidelines, technical and process safety information were utilized where appropriate. 

5.0 PSM / RMP Program Design 
The complete program ensures comprehensive coverage of process areas handling anhydrous 
ammonia and application of process safety controls. The program is designed to ensure safe 
operation of the anhydrous ammonia now and in the future. 

PSM / RMP systems are a structured, systematic method to implement an identified set of 
acti

vities with assigned responsibilities to achieve safe operation and to reduce the likelihood of 
a catastrophic release of hazardous chemicals. The various management systems (or PSM 
elements) combine into a PSM program. 

6.0 Process Descriptions and Overview 
SuperValu Foods Distribution Center, Indianola, Mississippi operates an ammonia refrigeration 
system to produce space cooling, product cooling, and process equipment cooling. 

The SuperValu Foods Distribution Center refrigeration system is designed to provide: 

A? Operating flexibility (through availability of multiple operating equipment 
combinations); 
A? Efficiency of operations (through the use of operating pressures commensurate with 
the degree of cooling required in the various refrigerated areas); 
A? Safety performance (through the minimal use of pumps, the installation of area 
ammonia monitors and system emergency shutdowns); and 
A? Consistency of operation, utilizing programmable logic controllers (PLCs) to 
monitor, record, operate, and modulate refrigeration equipment as conditions require.

SuperValu Foods Distribution-Lewis Grocer A? Indianola, MS 
Ammonia Refrigeration System 
Block and Flow Diagram 

10/08 



8.0 Ammonia Refrigeration System Overview 
8.1 Compression 
Gaseous ammonia is compressed utilizing any of 5 compressors, discharging at a nominal 
150 to 160 psig. Discharge pressure may run as high as 170 psig, depending upon the 
operating condi

tions and weather conditions. The high-stage compressors are utilized as 
the base-loaded machines. One or a combination of the base load compressors are 
operated at any time. Depending on the refrigeration needs, additional compressors may 
be required to move gaseous ammonia to the condensers for the additional refrigerant 
requirements. When additional compressors are needed beyond the base load 
compressors 3 and 5 are operationally added to the base-loaded machines during periods 
of increased cooling demand. . 

8.2 Condensing 
The high pressure, high temperature ammonia gas is condensed into liquid using any 
operating scheme of the 2 rooftop evaporative condensers. The evaporative condensers 
utilize a combination of water-cooling and multiple-speed fans to transfer heat from the 
refrigerant to the environment. The liquid ammonia is collected in the high pressure 
liquid receiver. 

8.3 Receiver 
High pressure ammonia liquid flows directly from the pilot high pressure liquid receiver 
to the high side recirculator to the low side recirculator. Then ammonia is transferred to 
room cooling air units (evaporators) where ammonia is evaporated inside coils to produce 
refrigeration. The evaporated gas is compressed and condensed into liquid and returned 
to the receiver. 

8.4 Recirculators 
The liquid levels in the recirculators are maintained through float columns and 
instrumentation. From the recirculators, high-pressure liquid ammonia (60 psig) flows to 
the various air units / evaporators, where it is admitted through flooded and direct 
expansion evaporators. There, heat energy from the area being cooled is used to 
evaporate the liquid ammonia into a gas. 



8.5 Demand for Cooling (House Suction) 
The amount of liquid ammonia evaporated is determined by the demand for cooling 
established by the set point of the thermostats of the various areas to be cooled. The 
gaseous ammonia is evaporated on the high side at approximately 25 psig, providing a 
nomi

nal +10A? F temperature. 

8.6 Evaporation 
The mixture of gaseous and liquid ammonia, evaporate from the air units / evaporators 
while absorbing heat from the refrigerated room. From the evaporator, the liquid 
ammonia is returned to the recirculator and the gaseous ammonia is returned to the 
compressors, where pressure and temperature is increased and discharged to the 
condenser to begin the cycle again. 

8.7 Emergency 
The ammonia refrigeration system has several safety features. In the event of a liquid 
ammonia leak, the pump outlet valves (outlet of the recirculators) can be closed manually 
to prevent flow of ammonia liquid to downstream equipment. The system mechanical 
equipment can be shutdown by the computer control system or by an emergency stop 
station located in the old engine room located north of the new engine room entrance. 
 


9.0 Ammonia System Summary 
9.1 Major equipment components include: 
A? 5 Compressors A? 23 Evaporators 
A? 2 Evaporative Condensers A? 1 Purger 
A? 2 Liquid Recirculators A? 4 Ammonia Pumps 
A? 1 High Pressure Liquid Pilot Receiver 
A? 1 Glycol Heat Exchanger 
9.2 Ammonia inventory: is estimated at 18,500 pounds. 
9.3 Ammonia system operators: One and one assistant operator. 
9.4 Ammonia System Contractor: Alta: 866-554-1150 or 678-554-1150 
Secondary: Southeastern Refrigeration, phone: 800-405-2146 or 205-322-6587 
10.0 Overall Responsibility 
The Facilities Maintenance Supervisor has been designated as having the overall responsibility 
for the development, implementation, and integration of the risk management and PSM program 
elements.
